content:
, 2014
Early Access Review
								Neo scavanger Is a awsome game period, Dont let the screen shots or videos fool you this game is great its crazy in depth and the plot is tried and true, the game is so amazing that I could cut down a tree limb and combine it with a tarp I had found to make a lean to, or take a pot and fire to boil my water to make it safe to drink, These are just a small sample of the variety of things you can create, it almost feels like if you can think it you can do it, Very few games other than project zomboid (also an amazing game) seem to be able to give you this sense of depth, The game is played by reading text and moving your character in a grid overworld kinda like final fantasy tactics, I will admit from screenshots I said this game will suck and its not for me....Boy was I wrong just get the demo play it and Im sure you will buy it, This is the only game I have ever played that I killed a man just for his left boot, This game is hard it wants you to die, but each time you do you learn from it and the next time you will go a little farther this style of gameplay is very rewarding do yourself a favor and pick up neo scavanger, In its current early access state I give it a 9/10 amazing.

content:
29, 2014
Early Access Review
								NEO Scavenger now has my full recommendation.This game has some deep tactical roots to it. A turned based rogue-like where you start off in the most startling position of weakness I could possibly imagine. “Scavenger” is the name of the game but this key aspect and function serves as a means to an end, and that end is survival. You wake up in a cryogenic facility with nothing of use but a hospital gown, medical bracelet. You're soon attacked by a supernatural creature, setting the tone for the brutal reality of survival, which seems to be the biggest note of the game. Notice I didn’t mention any shoes or memories. You’re barefoot and it’s autumn. No way to go through life in my humble opinion. I guess there’s a story about finding your identity or finding out what happened to the world.Sounds interesting, right? Like “28 Days Later” meets “DayZ”. I couldn’t tell you, because basically I’ve spent my hours just trying to survive against... get ready for it... Starvation. Food is scarce. I once savored a small packet of crackers for sustenance. I recently died trying to hunt a dangerous creature in what felt like a very realistic and thought out exchange in combat.Hydration. Water is not as scarce, but takes up storage space and the effects of dehydration can onset quickly leaving you weaker to take on the rigors of survival and ultimately lead to death.Hypothermia. It always seems cold and rainy. One play-through I traveled west for 12 hours and died of hypothermia desperately trying to find some degree of shelter or warmth.Brain damage and severe blood loss. Some people seem to be opportunists in this new and horrifying setting, attacking you on sight. You can try to reason with them or beat them to death or submission. Either way combat has to be dealt with or avoided one way or another. There are also inhumane beasts, such as the dogman who(that?) recently severed an artery in my leg, taking a fluke victory in what was described to me as brutal combat. The turned based combat plays out very interestingly, giving you often unique choices based on your surroundings, tools and skill set. In addition to normal attacks with your weaponry you often have different tactical options in a fight, like a trip or a head-butt. Leaving your opponent stunned and vulnerable is a key to winning conflicts and staying healthy. Wounds need attention and in a very animalistic way you need to learn that just because you can best a being in mortal combat it doesn’t necessarily mean he can be your prey.  The spoils of war are all well and good but damn well better be worth the cost of an open wound or wounded limb.Luckily there seems to be a wide array of technology, pharmaceuticals and med-kits to be found in your mysterious surroundings, everything seems to have something more to it. There's a vast world of crafting, trapping and other skills I've only touched the surface of. Hacking with a laptop can be far more effective than hacking with a cleaver.  Storage plays as big of a roll as anything I have mentioned thus far. I really enjoy the vast inventory options and the various challenges that arrive. The tools available to you in moving your life supporting cargo are just as varied. Plastic bags can be used as a light and spacious backpack but they quickly deteriorate under such use, a true backpack can handle much more rigors. Sleds can be used to drag your sleeping bag and other supplies but is outclassed by a modified shopping cart as a vehicle.Light sources can play a big part in safe scavenging, night time or not. Lighters run out of butane though, and flashlights need batteries. You often consume some of your items durability upon use as you scavenge for that rare useful weapon and equally sparse ammunition. There are some hiccups in this surprisingly immersive experience, like a lack of a local leaderboard and tracking or rating of your statistics and progress. The game doesn’t seem to integrate with windows well on start-up, but this is easily fixable in the settings. The aural potential of this game seems unrealized and the atmospheric tune that plays throughout doesn’t do enough for me. The lack of sound just about the only thing holding me back from having a more immersed experience.The slightly crude graphics and the fact that it is a Java game may be off putting to some, but those willing to look past the amateur feel will be rewarded with a view into this game’s deep, brutal, intelligent soul. The sense and reality of a true, terrifying post-apocalyptic survival setting seems fully represented. Made by Blue Bottle Games, which from what I can tell is just one dude, this frisky indie title feels like a true labor of love towards the bleak reality of our impending doom. 8.5/10

								I stumbled across this game while searching through for survival games. I took a look at the screenshots, and wasn't drawn to this game at all, however I saw there was a demo, and so decided to give it a go. To my surprise, I loved it almost instantly. The map is sort of half randomised, the main places of interest always in the same place, but forests, hills, towns, all completely random, so there's always something slightly different at the start of the game.Yes it's in early access, and maybe there'll be some more added to the storyline, maybe some more items, but for me it feels almost finished already, all full package, and I would totally reccommend at least trying the demo for this game. Give it a chance, even if you think you won't like it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 20, 2013
Early Access Review
								This game is unlike any I have played in the last two decades. I recommend it to anyone who wants a turn-based hex RPG. Set in a post-apocolyptic Lovecraftian Michigan, your character emerges from a crygenic vat to step into a race against time. You can die from dehydration, starvation, disease  and hypothermia, in addition to wounds inflicted by the various denizens surrounding the Motor City's wastelands. This hard setting is further amplified by the decision not to include a leveling system. Each time you play, you learn more about the game mechanics and possibilities. You can augment your character with four of a dozen advantages, as well as about six disadvantages. Thes combination of these influence your play style, as some opportunities only present themselves to those with a given trait. For those who love to play first-person shooter "RPG" as murder hobos, this is not the game for you. It is more reminiscent of games from the late 1980s and early 1990s in that it tells its story in a piecemeal fashion with only one Rouge-like save option. While you can engage in combat, you will frequently die. Stealth, scavanging and crafting reveal much more of the story, and further contribute to the desperation as you try to unravel not only how you came to be cycled out of the cryogenics tank, but also what happened to create this near-future landscape. Expect to die a lot. And enjoy it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								First and foremost, do not take my above playtime as my experience, I've bought it on Desura and the Website, and I wanted a third save and to give an additional amount of money to the devs. (Why can't I just give you money?!) Anyhow, this is Neo Scavenger in a nutshell:      Cold. How long has it been since I've been warm. A day? Ten? I don't know any more, time seems so eternal out here, and I've lost track of it. I don't know anything but pain, fear, and cold these days... and hunger. I tried building a campfire a while back, and that damned Bandit left me bleeding and scarred. I went looking for some medical equipment later that night, an an apartment collapsed on me. I'm weak and tired, but I'm too afraid to sleep... But I can afford to close my eyes a bit, right?...     "Give up all your f***ing gear if you want to live!" Before I'm even fully aware, I'm staring into the muzzle of a revolver. I panic and begin to scream, and he whacks me across the face with the revolver's butt.     "What? You f***ing deaf? Hand it all over!" I'm not deaf, but I'm not stupid either. If I hand over all this gear, I might live a while longer, but I'd still die. Slower and even more painfully than if he shot me. Besides, he might even be bluffing? Before he knows what's happening, I slam a heavy punch into his chest, knocking the wind out of his lungs and freezing him for a moment. Not one to waste, I use that moment. I grab a heavy-looking stone on the ground and begin to pummel him. In the dark, I see nothing but a vague grey shape. I slam the stone into his stomach, and he screams in pain. I pummel him even further, and further... Long after he dies, I'm still hitting him with the stone. My arms are aching and my head is pulsing, but I keep hitting the battered corpse. Finally, I relent. More out of exhaustion and pain rather than any sense of logic.     Then, I sleep. Fitfully and weakly at first, but soon enough, my fatigue catches up to me, and I rest. When I wake up, the full realization of what I'd done caught up to me. The "bandit" was a starving emaciated skeletal husk, and his revolver was a rusted abomination that was more likely to explode rather than fire. I begin to suck in a hitching, weak breath as I sob. That could have been me, and it probably would be before long...     It's been a while since I killed that man, but the heavy black weight of it hangs heavily on my shoulders. I hate my own existence, and have long considered suicide... If this isn't hell, then what is it? Just as I begin to slip the bottle of sedatives out of my pocket, I see a man approaching me. I haven't seen another sould in so long... and I feel genuine joy and excitement at the prospect of talking to someone... Maybe even make a friend? I begin to rush towards him, hands in the air to signify my friendliness. Before I know what happens, I am knocked aside the head, and looted.     This is Neo Scavenger, and though your adventure may not last as long, or be as miserly, you will experience the highs and lows of survival. You will wonder: "Why? Why did it have to end this way?" And you will face many hard choices.     Do both your practical intellect and your inner masochist a favour, and buy this game. It's well worth it's price.

content:
4, 2014
Early Access Review
								NEO Scavenger is a rogue-like survival game that was originally made in Flash.You control a character with amnesia or a version of memory loss, it is your job to make sure you survive in the vast post-apocalyptic landscape filled with mutants and raiders. The game involves turn-based combat and crafting which both give the game that unique gameplay style that makes it stand out amongst other titles. (May not sound like it, but it really is different)The game is hard, I really do mean hard. The rogue-like genre means that when you die or lose in game you will need to restart from the beginning, it also means that each map is procedurally generated and so there will never be the same items or NPC's in a single location. With the difficulty aside the game is really fun with a lot of replayability, there is no real storyline yet but it will be soon implemented according to the dev.At the time of writing this review it is still in the beta stage of development and also in Early Access, from what I have seen and played it is one of the few Early Access games that haven't disappointed me.

content:
3, 2014
												This is the most realistic survival game I have ever played, and due to the current stance of the industry I doubt anything will beat it for a very long time.The game mechanics are ridiculously realistic. Seriously, sometimes I die within the first 2 minutes of playing. Each and every single move you take could be your last, and this is not a game that becomes easy over time as you learn how to play it. This is a true survival game unlike any other.The mechanics are very balanced, and you have to do many things to survive. The crafting and inventory system is very nice, as it allows for a lot of customisation. Do not let the graphics of this game fool you, as the gameplay is what matters here. I personally really like the art style and retro feel to the game anyway.If you really want to know how much time the developer spent on making this game, here is an example: If you try and put minature items such as pebbles into a shopping cart, it won't work because in real life the pebbles would fall through the wire framing of the cart. Despite this being a very minor and insignificant example, it goes to show you how much the developer cares about the game.

content:
26, 2014
Early Access Review
								It is not often you find a roguelike where all the tables are even from the start. Where the skill of you, the player, makes all the difference, and not simply how much time you have spent making your character stronger. That won't happen in this game. On top of all of that, and no matter how much gear you find, how good a weapon you have, how sharp your skills have become. There will always be something that can kill you.As day breaks, I spot hiding in the nearby woods, a creature that is both man and beast. To my luck, I find the target unawares, at rest. Creeping in closer, spear in hand, I get in close, so close, hoping that the beast will not notice. The rain works in my favor here, and before the beast has a chance to act, I pull back and plunge my spear deep into the creatures eye socket. Your life, can end just as easily.After the battle, I take out my trusty pocketknife and get to work, pulling the flesh from the bone, and using my skills to keep the pelt in one piece. Trophy in hand, I sling the pelt over my shoulders. Both as proof of my skills in combat, but also, I will not freeze. Not tonight.

Early Access Review
								NEO Scavenger now has my full recommendation.This game has some deep tactical roots to it. A turned based rogue-like where you start off in the most startling position of weakness I could possibly imagine. “Scavenger” is the name of the game but this key aspect and function serves as a means to an end, and that end is survival. You wake up in a cryogenic facility with nothing of use but a hospital gown, medical bracelet. You're soon attacked by a supernatural creature, setting the tone for the brutal reality of survival, which seems to be the biggest note of the game. Notice I didn’t mention any shoes or memories. You’re barefoot and it’s autumn. No way to go through life in my humble opinion. I guess there’s a story about finding your identity or finding out what happened to the world.Sounds interesting, right? Like “28 Days Later” meets “DayZ”. I couldn’t tell you, because basically I’ve spent my hours just trying to survive against... get ready for it... Starvation. Food is scarce. I once savored a small packet of crackers for sustenance. I recently died trying to hunt a dangerous creature in what felt like a very realistic and thought out exchange in combat.Hydration. Water is not as scarce, but takes up storage space and the effects of dehydration can onset quickly leaving you weaker to take on the rigors of survival and ultimately lead to death.Hypothermia. It always seems cold and rainy. One play-through I traveled west for 12 hours and died of hypothermia desperately trying to find some degree of shelter or warmth.Brain damage and severe blood loss. Some people seem to be opportunists in this new and horrifying setting, attacking you on sight. You can try to reason with them or beat them to death or submission. Either way combat has to be dealt with or avoided one way or another. There are also inhumane beasts, such as the dogman who(that?) recently severed an artery in my leg, taking a fluke victory in what was described to me as brutal combat. The turned based combat plays out very interestingly, giving you often unique choices based on your surroundings, tools and skill set. In addition to normal attacks with your weaponry you often have different tactical options in a fight, like a trip or a head-butt. Leaving your opponent stunned and vulnerable is a key to winning conflicts and staying healthy. Wounds need attention and in a very animalistic way you need to learn that just because you can best a being in mortal combat it doesn’t necessarily mean he can be your prey.  The spoils of war are all well and good but damn well better be worth the cost of an open wound or wounded limb.Luckily there seems to be a wide array of technology, pharmaceuticals and med-kits to be found in your mysterious surroundings, everything seems to have something more to it. There's a vast world of crafting, trapping and other skills I've only touched the surface of. Hacking with a laptop can be far more effective than hacking with a cleaver.  Storage plays as big of a roll as anything I have mentioned thus far. I really enjoy the vast inventory options and the various challenges that arrive. The tools available to you in moving your life supporting cargo are just as varied. Plastic bags can be used as a light and spacious backpack but they quickly deteriorate under such use, a true backpack can handle much more rigors. Sleds can be used to drag your sleeping bag and other supplies but is outclassed by a modified shopping cart as a vehicle.Light sources can play a big part in safe scavenging, night time or not. Lighters run out of butane though, and flashlights need batteries. You often consume some of your items durability upon use as you scavenge for that rare useful weapon and equally sparse ammunition. There are some hiccups in this surprisingly immersive experience, like a lack of a local leaderboard and tracking or rating of your statistics and progress. The game doesn’t seem to integrate with windows well on start-up, but this is easily fixable in the settings. The aural potential of this game seems unrealized and the atmospheric tune that plays throughout doesn’t do enough for me. The lack of sound just about the only thing holding me back from having a more immersed experience.The slightly crude graphics and the fact that it is a Java game may be off putting to some, but those willing to look past the amateur feel will be rewarded with a view into this game’s deep, brutal, intelligent soul. The sense and reality of a true, terrifying post-apocalyptic survival setting seems fully represented. Made by Blue Bottle Games, which from what I can tell is just one dude, this frisky indie title feels like a true labor of love towards the bleak reality of our impending doom. 8.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
4, 2014
Early Access Review
								NEO Scavenger is a rogue-like survival game that was originally made in Flash.You control a character with amnesia or a version of memory loss, it is your job to make sure you survive in the vast post-apocalyptic landscape filled with mutants and raiders. The game involves turn-based combat and crafting which both give the game that unique gameplay style that makes it stand out amongst other titles. (May not sound like it, but it really is different)The game is hard, I really do mean hard. The rogue-like genre means that when you die or lose in game you will need to restart from the beginning, it also means that each map is procedurally generated and so there will never be the same items or NPC's in a single location. With the difficulty aside the game is really fun with a lot of replayability, there is no real storyline yet but it will be soon implemented according to the dev.At the time of writing this review it is still in the beta stage of development and also in Early Access, from what I have seen and played it is one of the few Early Access games that haven't disappointed me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								First and foremost, do not take my above playtime as my experience, I've bought it on Desura and the Website, and I wanted a third save and to give an additional amount of money to the devs. (Why can't I just give you money?!) Anyhow, this is Neo Scavenger in a nutshell:      Cold. How long has it been since I've been warm. A day? Ten? I don't know any more, time seems so eternal out here, and I've lost track of it. I don't know anything but pain, fear, and cold these days... and hunger. I tried building a campfire a while back, and that damned Bandit left me bleeding and scarred. I went looking for some medical equipment later that night, an an apartment collapsed on me. I'm weak and tired, but I'm too afraid to sleep... But I can afford to close my eyes a bit, right?...     "Give up all your f***ing gear if you want to live!" Before I'm even fully aware, I'm staring into the muzzle of a revolver. I panic and begin to scream, and he whacks me across the face with the revolver's butt.     "What? You f***ing deaf? Hand it all over!" I'm not deaf, but I'm not stupid either. If I hand over all this gear, I might live a while longer, but I'd still die. Slower and even more painfully than if he shot me. Besides, he might even be bluffing? Before he knows what's happening, I slam a heavy punch into his chest, knocking the wind out of his lungs and freezing him for a moment. Not one to waste, I use that moment. I grab a heavy-looking stone on the ground and begin to pummel him. In the dark, I see nothing but a vague grey shape. I slam the stone into his stomach, and he screams in pain. I pummel him even further, and further... Long after he dies, I'm still hitting him with the stone. My arms are aching and my head is pulsing, but I keep hitting the battered corpse. Finally, I relent. More out of exhaustion and pain rather than any sense of logic.     Then, I sleep. Fitfully and weakly at first, but soon enough, my fatigue catches up to me, and I rest. When I wake up, the full realization of what I'd done caught up to me. The "bandit" was a starving emaciated skeletal husk, and his revolver was a rusted abomination that was more likely to explode rather than fire. I begin to suck in a hitching, weak breath as I sob. That could have been me, and it probably would be before long...     It's been a while since I killed that man, but the heavy black weight of it hangs heavily on my shoulders. I hate my own existence, and have long considered suicide... If this isn't hell, then what is it? Just as I begin to slip the bottle of sedatives out of my pocket, I see a man approaching me. I haven't seen another sould in so long... and I feel genuine joy and excitement at the prospect of talking to someone... Maybe even make a friend? I begin to rush towards him, hands in the air to signify my friendliness. Before I know what happens, I am knocked aside the head, and looted.     This is Neo Scavenger, and though your adventure may not last as long, or be as miserly, you will experience the highs and lows of survival. You will wonder: "Why? Why did it have to end this way?" And you will face many hard choices.     Do both your practical intellect and your inner masochist a favour, and buy this game. It's well worth it's price.

content:
1, 2014
Early Access Review
								I haven't reviewed anything on Steam yet, but I had to review NEO Scavenger because this game deserves so much praise. It completely caught me by surprise and is a great example of Early Access done right. I paid the $9.99 awhile ago and I felt it was completely worth it, and after the frequent updates and improvements, it definitely continues to be worth the money. While I do think the UI needs to be cleaned up a little and the story could be fleshed out more, NEO Scavenger is still a great game. From the crafting that is more than just there because a ton of games are including it, to the way it draws you in for one more turn, and then another, and then maybe another hour goes by, I couldn't say enough good things. There are some flaws and it isn't for everyone, but check out the demo and support a developer that does Early Access right. I've so far put nearly 30 hours into NEO Scavenger and I'll definitely be adding to that number as time goes on

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
4, 2014
Early Access Review
								I spent a lot of time looking for a good scavenging/crafting/surviving experience. Since stalker: call of pripyat I felt kind of left in the bench, but Neo scavenger totaly have potential for it! It feels like actual surviving, having to find food, clothes, shelter, water, tools, weapons, decide if you run or fight in an encounter, craft things etc. every mistakes can be paid the high price, the global experience is impressively convincing!The game's really hard tho, I keep dying in so many different ways, which is great as surviving shouldn't be easy, but the permadeath makes it really hard on the player, you barely start to get some good stuffs and die to start from the beghining again. It's really frustrating, but the difficulty of the game make it so deliciously painful ^^The game is still on developement so criticizing is probably prematured, but i'd like to signal that the rarity and price of ammunitions makes it unworthy to equip anything else than melee weapons, also (maybe it's a bug) when the cart broke i lost all my stuffs inside on many occasions, which doesn't make sens, as if the cart broke the stuffs shouldn't just disapear and be on the ground for me to save what i can... And last thing, the food/water mechanism isn't really logic, as you'll starve almost as fast as you'll get dehydrated, eating 50kg of berries will feed you for barely a few hours and they're pretty hard to find when you need them.Here's a few thing I'd love to see implemented/improved, hopefully devs would read it (who knows ^^) and find some indeas interesting, also maybe some things i suggest here are allready in the game/planed and I haven't found out yet, sorry if it happen:-Ability to cancel last action, as sometime i click on the wrong square or make mistakes while crafting.-Fixing the strarvation system: human body can last over 40 days without food, it doesn't make sense to die from starvation after barely 2 days. Maybe splitting "well fed" with "hungry" and "bulk", where "hungry" would affect your action points, fight capability, scavenging ability etc. While "bulk" would be your global "well fed" status, going from overweight (which inflict handicap), to anorexic which make "hunger" constantly low and starvation deadly. Also the meat spoils really fast, i'm not sure if it's unrealistic but why not some ways to make it last longer, like an hermetic bag, lunch boxes, thermal backpack or something.-The combat interface is pretty hard to understand, sometime i just get attacked out of nowhere while sleeping (which is pretty cool), but the guy turns out to be badly stuffed and wreck me out in couple hits, leaving me no other option than crie while watching my character die in horrible pain. Maybe something signaling the global risk of the oponent and/or chances of successfull attacks, dodges, escapes etc. Just so we know if we can try a fight or just drop all our ♥♥♥♥♥ out and run the hell away.-How can't a medic + botanic find some antidotes in forests? I keep dying from poisoning without having any chance of reaching the clinic. Also, items in general lacks a description of their effects as well as statuses leave you wondering how to fix them i'd like to have a hint of what everything does or need to be fixed (for ex: antibiotics: can heal X, or dissentry: can be healed with X).-When crafting, have a picture of each craftable item in the recipes list, this would ease a lot the recipe's browsing.-Pliz, just pliz, more ammunitions, I gave up using any weapon as i take hours to find only 3 bullets, and allways for the one weapon you don't have, i love to shoot things, but in a week of playing I had the chance to do so about 3 times only.-I would LOVE to be able to fix items, for example taking parts of one gun to fix another gun, it makes a lot of sense and have been seen in many crafting/rogue-like games (such as fallout or 7days to die), I really love that feature as you don't waste good finds (like guns, backpacks, carts etc...) just because you allready have one that's in a barely better condition.-More shopz! there is only one shop, and it's near town which mean if you want to farm cash, buy ammunitions, buy food etc. You'll have to go all the way there, across that lifeless desert of empty buildings and rude people that won't let you kill and eat them, I died a LOT starving just trying to reach it, why not itinerant sellers or random shops in some ruins?-Ability to settle. I mean it's a surviving game, greatly done, but you can't make you home anywhere, why not the ability to choose a place to fortify, stock food, make confortable shelter, medical supplies, and (why not) working benches that allows you to fix things, craft more, that require tools to enable some special crafts etc. -Definitly more scavenging places, and more specifics ones, like pharmacies, gunshops, supermarkets, factories... We all love those.-Reinforce the "friendly encounters" potential, right now it's mostly neutral/ennemy, maybe we could meet some people that help us, offer trades, indicate to locations etc.-The ability to loot money from innocent victi... people i killed in legitimate defense, I mean there is money in the game, how come no one carry any? -More weapons and more craftability in weapons, like the ability to upgrade a rifle (kind of like in stalker, i really loved that feature) to make it more deadly. Also the ability to craft bullets would be nice.-Skill learning, I don't get why there is so much slots available while you can't chose more than 5 to about 8 skills, i get it for the start, but then i'd like to have a way to learn new skills ingame after a while.-Even biger map. I know this one is huge allready, but in the end there's nothing but one city and the start facility (plus the ruins of course) I'd love to see more special places, more terrains, more climates... more surprises!-More hunting potential, I managed to kill a dear once, but with no ammunitions and no way to come near them and oneshot them, it's really hard to get any, so the moral choice of rather eating or not human flesh become a rethorical question: you just can't survive without your daily bad mutha's barbecue, I'd like to play it "nice guy" sometime and eat only berries and animal meat, but it need more dears and squirels, and even bunnies, rats, birds etc.. Traps also are underated, we should be able to put one in the forest and come back later to see if it caught something.-Maps markers, like if i have to drop my loot for some reason, I can mark the place to come back later, this could combine with the previous traps comment to know where you had put a trap, and make you come back to check them before your catch get stolen (by a thief or another animal) or spoils.-More detailed medicinal interraction: risks of local wound infection (that can turn to septisemia of not cured), specific intervention required (tools needed to pull out an arrow, suturation, hemoragy, broken bones etc.)-Difficulty choice/save game, as it's pretty frustrating to start all over everytime you die, i'd personnally like to be able to save my games at some points, maybe make it hard like having to find a saving location in the map etc.  An alternative would be to propose 2 game modes: hardcore (permadeath) and softcore (respaw with penalties).-Zombies, lol joke, the game is allready great, it doesn't even need zombies (i'm not sure some zombie-like creatures would ruin it tho).That's about all I can think of right now, but anyway the game rocks! I really hope you guys will push it to the best of it's potential, and for the players still hesitating: go for it! It's worth every penny!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
r 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is genuinely superb. There are many, many ways in which you can approach the simple task you are given - survive, and all of them are satysfying yet challenging. All the traits you get to choose while creating your character are massively useful and impactful and you can only take a few, heavily influencing how you play. What's more, the game is suprisingly fair for a rougelike - i've been killed without any chance at defending or escaping only once, while sleeping in some town ruins (which is obviously not a smart idea as these are heavily contested by looters and scavengers and i should have expected something like that to happen). The combat system is very entertaining and has some neat depth to it, at least when you are fighting on even ground. If you assault a random, starving unarmed guy with a spear there won't be any challenge, but with the same spear you can try to take on mutants, soldiers, and hunting-rifle wielding manhunters if you have the right traits and choose your moves wisely. Or you can lure those guys into some other guys, have them fight, and then move in to scavenge their stuff. Or just run and try to avoid them. Your life often depends on decisions like that, and it's quite brilliant.

If you want to buy this game, you should.

content:
6, 2014
Early Access Review
								That game is now in my favorite games ever played.It's one of those rare games that you get a feeling of accomplishment when you get some valuable loot and manage to keep it for a long period of time. Even if you die and have to start back from the cryo lab and the beginning is always the same, it's really easy to have a completly different experience while you play. You will never encounter the same enemy during your first travel to one place and you will really need luck to survive some obstacles (for example, someone steal all your stuff while you sleep, including your clothes. The amount luck you'll need to survive that is really really big).You know that you've progressed in this game when you look back at the main event that happened during your journey. From when you left that cryo lab with only a hospital gown with you and when you just killed 5 dogman with your rifle and your compound bow.Speaking of combat, this is one of the games where you feel more cruel when you kill someone than in a FPS game, and you dont even see it happen! It's just click and hope to read something that is good for you! Even if you are not reading a book each time you use an attack, you'll feel very cruel when you'll read that he died by lung bleeding, so you basically caused him to drown in his own blood.Anyway, go buy this game now! Its really worth it!15/10

y 17, 2015
												This game is great!  Paid for itself the first day.  Ultimate replayability, the crafting system is excellent, no lack of challenge and great stories.  I feel like this should be the alpha version of this game as there is soooo much potential here.  Stirke a deal with sid meyer's if you can, but either way this game needs to be much bigger and available everywhere. Needs more spawn locations, add animated battle sequences (though I wouldn't mess too much with the battle system you've got), more craftables (this suggestion will never change, you can never have too many craftables), online maps, more gangs, recruit a crew and start your own gang and the obvious one, upgradeable and interchangeable skills.  I realize this game has just recently released and not a moment too soon.  Despite my long list of suggested improvements for future patches/releases, this game is a solid WIN!  (though I did manage to sneak past most of the story line and beat the game by wandering to the north, so you might want to address that too).  I highly recommend to everyone who enjoys turn-base, post-apocalyptic and/or crafting survival, styles. I would buy it as a phone app too.  Keep up the good work guys and gals!  and never forget about us mac gamers.  We know we're a pain to accomodate, but we need the mac for work (most of us) and I lose out on money to sacrifice disk space to run games, but that's our level of dedication.

content:
y 8, 2016
												Note: I bought and played mostly on the GOG version of the game, hence why I have less than 2 hours in Steam. I probably logged over 100 hours.Anyways...What this game does right is giving you lots of options when it comes to survival. Too often survival games feel limited, like things you should be able to do easily in a real life situation just aren't available in game. A couple examples that come to mind:- Need to boil something but don't have a cooking pot? Use a tin can!- Need to make fire but don't have a lighter? Rub two sticks together or use sunlight and a piece of glass!- Need a container to carry items but don't have a backpack? Use a plastic shopping bag!- Need bandages? Rip clothes, get rags. Need clean bandages? Boil rags.- Need string? Rip rags.Nice features include:- 'Building' your camp: pick an abandoned building with the appliances you need, place traps, leave a sleeping bag... Not a whole lot of options but you do feel like you have your own personal secure spot you can come back to.- An engaging storyline that makes you want to find out about what happened to the world and yourself. An interesting lore as well.- Lots of crafting options to get the stuff you need to survive.- Skills that give you special abilities- Pretty good learning curve: you'll have to keep trying at first until you learn the basics. Then you'll manage to survive fairly well, and you'll still have many more things to learn and discover. There's lots of stuff you'll have to figure out on your own (or you can use the wiki).- Overall, enough content to keep you engaged for many hours.- Low hardware requirements. Will probably run on that $200 laptop you bought to take notes in class (check the specs to be sure though).Cons:- The game is text-based with a graphical interface. Nothing is animated, few things are drawn, most is just described through text. The combat system especially takes some getting used too as well. It's very playable and some people like that style, but for some people it's a deal-breaker. So be warned.- Only one save/permadeath (although you can easily circumvent that).- Not being able to pick all skills can make the game feel limited, forcing you to play again to explore other things (you can mod the game to get all skills though).- The randomness can be harsh sometimes and force you to restart many times before you'll get lucky, have a good start and actually get somewhere.- Many random encounters don't have a "good" resolution to them, sometimes making you feel like the game just ties your hands excessively and won't let you try hard enough, or making you feel like your skills are useless. Some encounters can actually punish you severely, with no way for you to predict that your decisions will lead to a really bad outcome. This is in deep contrast with the rest of the game where you have so many options to accomplish what you want to do.Overall I recommend it to people who enjoy the survival genre, have the patience to fail, learn and try again repeatedly, and who can overlook the game sometimes throwing you in tough situations without you being able to do anything about it. People who aren't so hardcore can just mod the game a bit to make it easier and can circumvent the one save/permadeath feature.

content:
4, 2014
Early Access Review
								I spent a lot of time looking for a good scavenging/crafting/surviving experience. Since stalker: call of pripyat I felt kind of left in the bench, but Neo scavenger totaly have potential for it! It feels like actual surviving, having to find food, clothes, shelter, water, tools, weapons, decide if you run or fight in an encounter, craft things etc. every mistakes can be paid the high price, the global experience is impressively convincing!The game's really hard tho, I keep dying in so many different ways, which is great as surviving shouldn't be easy, but the permadeath makes it really hard on the player, you barely start to get some good stuffs and die to start from the beghining again. It's really frustrating, but the difficulty of the game make it so deliciously painful ^^The game is still on developement so criticizing is probably prematured, but i'd like to signal that the rarity and price of ammunitions makes it unworthy to equip anything else than melee weapons, also (maybe it's a bug) when the cart broke i lost all my stuffs inside on many occasions, which doesn't make sens, as if the cart broke the stuffs shouldn't just disapear and be on the ground for me to save what i can... And last thing, the food/water mechanism isn't really logic, as you'll starve almost as fast as you'll get dehydrated, eating 50kg of berries will feed you for barely a few hours and they're pretty hard to find when you need them.Here's a few thing I'd love to see implemented/improved, hopefully devs would read it (who knows ^^) and find some indeas interesting, also maybe some things i suggest here are allready in the game/planed and I haven't found out yet, sorry if it happen:-Ability to cancel last action, as sometime i click on the wrong square or make mistakes while crafting.-Fixing the strarvation system: human body can last over 40 days without food, it doesn't make sense to die from starvation after barely 2 days. Maybe splitting "well fed" with "hungry" and "bulk", where "hungry" would affect your action points, fight capability, scavenging ability etc. While "bulk" would be your global "well fed" status, going from overweight (which inflict handicap), to anorexic which make "hunger" constantly low and starvation deadly. Also the meat spoils really fast, i'm not sure if it's unrealistic but why not some ways to make it last longer, like an hermetic bag, lunch boxes, thermal backpack or something.-The combat interface is pretty hard to understand, sometime i just get attacked out of nowhere while sleeping (which is pretty cool), but the guy turns out to be badly stuffed and wreck me out in couple hits, leaving me no other option than crie while watching my character die in horrible pain. Maybe something signaling the global risk of the oponent and/or chances of successfull attacks, dodges, escapes etc. Just so we know if we can try a fight or just drop all our ♥♥♥♥♥ out and run the hell away.-How can't a medic + botanic find some antidotes in forests? I keep dying from poisoning without having any chance of reaching the clinic. Also, items in general lacks a description of their effects as well as statuses leave you wondering how to fix them i'd like to have a hint of what everything does or need to be fixed (for ex: antibiotics: can heal X, or dissentry: can be healed with X).-When crafting, have a picture of each craftable item in the recipes list, this would ease a lot the recipe's browsing.-Pliz, just pliz, more ammunitions, I gave up using any weapon as i take hours to find only 3 bullets, and allways for the one weapon you don't have, i love to shoot things, but in a week of playing I had the chance to do so about 3 times only.-I would LOVE to be able to fix items, for example taking parts of one gun to fix another gun, it makes a lot of sense and have been seen in many crafting/rogue-like games (such as fallout or 7days to die), I really love that feature as you don't waste good finds (like guns, backpacks, carts etc...) just because you allready have one that's in a barely better condition.-More shopz! there is only one shop, and it's near town which mean if you want to farm cash, buy ammunitions, buy food etc. You'll have to go all the way there, across that lifeless desert of empty buildings and rude people that won't let you kill and eat them, I died a LOT starving just trying to reach it, why not itinerant sellers or random shops in some ruins?-Ability to settle. I mean it's a surviving game, greatly done, but you can't make you home anywhere, why not the ability to choose a place to fortify, stock food, make confortable shelter, medical supplies, and (why not) working benches that allows you to fix things, craft more, that require tools to enable some special crafts etc. -Definitly more scavenging places, and more specifics ones, like pharmacies, gunshops, supermarkets, factories... We all love those.-Reinforce the "friendly encounters" potential, right now it's mostly neutral/ennemy, maybe we could meet some people that help us, offer trades, indicate to locations etc.-The ability to loot money from innocent victi... people i killed in legitimate defense, I mean there is money in the game, how come no one carry any? -More weapons and more craftability in weapons, like the ability to upgrade a rifle (kind of like in stalker, i really loved that feature) to make it more deadly. Also the ability to craft bullets would be nice.-Skill learning, I don't get why there is so much slots available while you can't chose more than 5 to about 8 skills, i get it for the start, but then i'd like to have a way to learn new skills ingame after a while.-Even biger map. I know this one is huge allready, but in the end there's nothing but one city and the start facility (plus the ruins of course) I'd love to see more special places, more terrains, more climates... more surprises!-More hunting potential, I managed to kill a dear once, but with no ammunitions and no way to come near them and oneshot them, it's really hard to get any, so the moral choice of rather eating or not human flesh become a rethorical question: you just can't survive without your daily bad mutha's barbecue, I'd like to play it "nice guy" sometime and eat only berries and animal meat, but it need more dears and squirels, and even bunnies, rats, birds etc.. Traps also are underated, we should be able to put one in the forest and come back later to see if it caught something.-Maps markers, like if i have to drop my loot for some reason, I can mark the place to come back later, this could combine with the previous traps comment to know where you had put a trap, and make you come back to check them before your catch get stolen (by a thief or another animal) or spoils.-More detailed medicinal interraction: risks of local wound infection (that can turn to septisemia of not cured), specific intervention required (tools needed to pull out an arrow, suturation, hemoragy, broken bones etc.)-Difficulty choice/save game, as it's pretty frustrating to start all over everytime you die, i'd personnally like to be able to save my games at some points, maybe make it hard like having to find a saving location in the map etc.  An alternative would be to propose 2 game modes: hardcore (permadeath) and softcore (respaw with penalties).-Zombies, lol joke, the game is allready great, it doesn't even need zombies (i'm not sure some zombie-like creatures would ruin it tho).That's about all I can think of right now, but anyway the game rocks! I really hope you guys will push it to the best of it's potential, and for the players still hesitating: go for it! It's worth every penny!

content:
29, 2014
Early Access Review
								Really great game. VERY addictive, so if you don't have much time to play games this may not be for you. Even in early access this game is very polished and I have yet to encounter a single bug. The choices you make during character creation significantly impact the way you play, and the threat of death from a variety of sources is omnipresent. Although the game is fairly complex, it's also pretty easy to get into because everything works as one would expect it to. For instance, I didn't need a guide or anything to figure out how to craft a campfire on my first attempt. That's not to say this game is easy, far from it: you are pretty much guaranteed to die a few times pretty quickly until you get the hang of things, but deaths in this game don't feel cheap or frustrating and I've never had a death that I didn't learn something from. Pretty much everything in this game is solid; the only thing I could say I want is more content because I have so loved what I have experienced that I want more.

content:
28, 2014
Early Access Review
								Very engrossing survival game where it actually feels like you struggle to survive. You have to watch what you eat and drink, make sure you’re clothed properly, and as the title suggest, scavenge the world for supplies and materials. Every time you play it's different, and it can come down to skill and some luck. There are interesting skills that provide you with a variety of crafting options that may otherwise be unavailable, or perks such as the ability to find more loot, get better information on your medical state, or craft certain items. Pretty good story (although I haven't gotten very far because I die a lot :D) Highly recommend to anyone who is into more hardcore survival games. The interface seemed strange at first, but after a few tries the combat and exploration became very engrossing, which I was not expecting from the screenshots. Highly recommended!

content:
er 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								Why I have stopped playing NEO Scavenger.  First of all congratulations on creating this game.  Its a very very good game. This is the first and possibly only review I have ever been compelled to write on steam and its something to be said for the quality of this game that I want to save this game for me and not put it in my discard pile. I hesitated about giving this a yes review for the reason that there is no save function.  I get what you are trying to do with death being death however after spending over one hundred hours and near twenty or thirty attempts just to get as far as the gate of detroit (once)... in the last three cases doing nothing but hunting and hiding in a forest making leather armour (mod?) for nigh on twenty hours of play time only to be slaughtered by two dog men half an hour after setting out for the city then doing the same thing in another game, spending this time ten hours (of real life time)  in a forest making leather armour only to be slaughtered by three men as soon as I left the forest not even being able to run away and then doing the same thing, ten hours in a forest hunting and making armour,  only to be slaughtered while I slept without even waking up even though I had multiple noise traps in place.  Then I tried cheating using a mod to add every skill but it had lost its charm because of this becoming too easy.  I dont want a walkthough,  want a hard playthrough but please not a hundred of them, I dont have the time. I have stopped playing this game because I dont have this sort of time to spend to get no where in a game.  I choose not to play again to try and get somewhere in the plot only then to later get slaughtered having spent a hundred hours progressing the plot and have to start all over again.  I want to play it through and I commend you for having this idea to have this "when your dead your dead" idea but I actually have a real life to survive in and I simply dont have time to spend too much of it locked into this game.  Yes, have an Iron man mode for the realism of the survival aspect of the game, but until there is a save function I will not be returning to this game.  I recommend this game to anyone who has a hundred hours to spend just to get out of the starting blocks.EDIT... I have changed this from NO to YES to NO to YES... Its too good not to reccomend.  And... then... I started another game... Dan... I hate you... I love you... I hate you... I love you... please add an iron man function your driving me insane.

content:
er 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								A nice premise - old style hex adventure, but with the usual apocalyse scenario.Its far from easy, for example anyone thinking of rushing headlong against mobs the moment you start should think again or you will die, and it will happen often. Sneak around scavenging for clothing, weapons... craft those bits of junk into something useable. Then go out again - you'll still get killed, but perhaps less often. This is a game of learning and trial & error. You will learn as you die. And you will learn as you survive. Its something of a slow burner. You WILL come back to it after a period of frustration. It'll sit there somewhere in your mind, suggesting you have another go - maybe this time...Permadeath has to be in the game or would essentially ruin the story, and essentially this is the driving force - this game can be replayed with different information based on your skillset - perhaps some things that would be hidden would be revealed.I feel some things that need improving - crafting for example is good, but would be best if it remembered every combination you'd come up with from previous games (rather like the old son of in the old rogue type games. This has some previous recipes but not many, and trying to remember them all yourself is absurd.Also something that (I think) needs changing to a degree is the way loot is calculated - many times you can obtain a hoard from scavenging with almost no chance to gain anything, but then you can repeatedly find nothing when you have a good chance. Certain skills improve or reduce this, but I think too much in some cases.Basically here is a potentially good game, which needs many more refinements before it can really be considered complete.I enjoy this sort of game, but I really wonder if I'm actually anything better than totally rubbish at them. The fact is that despite any faults - any time you have what you deem to be a completely unfair death or when you were just starting to do well for once then along comes... a big nasty monster... at least you have the knowledge of what doesnt work next time, or a different skill to pick - maybe you'll endure the early multitude of deaths and finish the game - perhaps I really am rubbish at it, maybe it (the game) needs balancing, or maybe it always will be just a tad too hard.In conclusion:I'd play it more if I didnt die as often, if I got to see slightly more of the story.All too often you go through the initial stages then die in a low level battle. Perhaps if you were just left sometimes with your stuff robbed - at least you had a little chance...7/10 (with potential to be 9/10)**SPOILER ALERT**Leave the talisman alone.

content:
er 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is a bit of a hard sell at first. The user interface is not exactly intuitive, and the graphics are nice but a bit retro.If you overcome these initial scepticisms though, what you'll find is a game that is a mixture of "A dark room" (minus the initial set-up phase), "Minecraft" (minus the blocky 3d graphics) and any Rougelike (so expect to die frequently).The basic setup is always the same: you wake up in some kind of cryo-lab, and the world outside has turned into a post-apocalyptic dystopia similar to "The Walking Dead" or "28 Days Later".You have to find out about your own past and uncover the secret of what happened to the world.You walk around the landscape on hex-grids, scavenging the woods or the remains of long-gone cities for clothes, food, water and weapons, while avoiding (at least initially) other NPCs or animals, most of which want to see you dead. You can craft things together with recipes you find scattered around randomly, and from time to time you find pieces of newspapers which tell you a bit about what has happened.The environment is highly dynamic, you have different weather patterns which impact your sight (when you find a scope or binoculars, you can even increase your visible range), and many other scavengers are roaming the area on their own (one nice example: I once found a corpse, looted it and moved his stuff into my hideout, just to find him chopped to bits of meat when I came back the next day... and of course the killer was not far off and killed me a few minutes later...)The story unfolds bit by bit (you have to survive the first night to even get an idea on where you should be moving), and even though I not yet come very far in the story yet (did I mention it is very easy to die in this game?) it is a game I will keep on coming back for "just one more try..."The only downside (IMHO) is that there is no way of saving the game (except for the "save&quit" function), so every death is permanent. And since it's written in Flash there's no easy way of getting the save data out for bakup purposes. But that just shows that it's a real Roguelike at heart...

content:
er 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is an awesome mix of survival, scavenger, skyrim, and a turn based combat game. The map is huge, consisting of hexagons which may or may not have item already on the ground, indicated by a box. The looking glass indicated scavenging. The tent indicates your camp sites, and finally the red feet indicate whether someone or you have been there recently.This game is not for the faint of heart. In the beginning, you die frequently and most often by things you wouldn't normally expect. There are NPC who are homicidal and roaming the wilds looking to 'scavenge' off your newly dead body. At first I could only last a few hours, and then I quickly learned the skills necessary to survive longer. My average now is 3 to 5 days. The skill/flaw system can be a little frustrating, and there aren't many of either. It could definitely use more of both to allow a better customization of the characters skills and flaws.On top of that, there is not a way to customize the characters name, gender, or gender-based clothing, at least none that I have discovered. This is truly a survive or die game. Weather, injuries, cold, hunger, thirst, disease, poison, and combat can all kill you. There are also random hex's that have NPC run stores in which you can trade things for money or for other items. The only city I have found as of yet is Detroit.The one resounding issue I have with this game is once you are dead... you are dead. There is no way to save unless you want to dink around in your computers files to rig up some kind save system. While the character is still alive, you can save and come back to your one save, but after death it disappears and you have to start over. I don't see a point in that system, but then again.. I didn't make the game. I think this game has some real potential. It can be frustrating, and seem difficult but failing has helped me learn how to survive longer and pick the skills necessary to survive. There are little things that I think could be corrected like in-game items, or the way in which skills are used. My favorite skills to use would be Trapping, Botany, Medic, Hiding, Tracking, Electrician, Mechanic, and a few others. I'd like to see a sewing skill and possibly the ability to take/train an animal companion. I know if I were trying to survive, I would try to find a dog to help protect my stuff, and me while sleeping.I am concerned though that the developers are making the game significantly harder, so I think the option to choose a skill level from safe - ultimate survivor could be used to allow many different people with varied experiences with games like this could play casually or have a challenge. I like being able to play through a game and then go back through it collecting all of the little dodads and whatnot. In conclusion, I love the basis of this game. I think a few things that need to be changed are the save games, a few additional items in game, a few additional skills and a few changes to how the skills work, a better skill/flaw menu, addition of companions, as well as a difficulty setting.A bug that I think I have found would be while wearing different shoes, or a single shoe still gives the negative effects of being barefoot. However if the two shoes are the same, the effect goes away.Great game, my fiance and I are addicted to it. Keep up the good work!

								Now I can't say much about the end game bits (If there even is an End game this game seems to last forever) but what I can say about this new update today, is it is WHOLEFULY welcomed. This update makes it so much better, gives a better balance to the beginning skills and some thing alittle bit less noticable is the beginning area is now dotted with more cities and towns which really increase your chances of finding some cloths or a backpack which are damnedfully welcomed. Now these changes do make the game slightly easier but hell this was probably the hardest game I own in my library. Now it's only the hardest game I own still. Lemme say how hard this bloody game is, it's harder than probably all the Darksoul bosses put in to one fight. I mean the environment will kill you, if a Bad Motha doesn't beat your brains out while you sleep, or the infamous shadow that just makes you explode basically. Even for a early access game I must be honest I feel like I'm getting a full game that is complete. I rarely find bugs, or any imbalaces. The Dev does a AAA job of keeping up with the community and the game. I've had a few early access games and by far this Dev really takes care of this game, like all devs should. So if you're a fan of Hexagon RPG, Survival, Mystery, Action, Adventure, Strategy, Turnbased Fun... or even one of those applies to you, I'd highly recommend getting this game. For $10 you honestly cannot go wrong with this game. 10/10 Would get stoned to death again.

content:
er 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								Well well well.  Now this is something quite good and interesting.This game has pleasently took me by surprise and I'm enjoying whats on offer so far.  Best way I can sort of explain this, is basically a Tactics style game with Text Adventure Role Playing elements set in an apocolyptic environment, coupled with...I guess Day Z/Rust style scavenging.I'm only just starting to understand the basics of the game, however it is quite enjoyable.  Basically you are person thats escaped from a facility and you must try and uncover who you are.  To do this you must survive going through the world and scavenging stuff that you need.  To do this, you enter locations and you must decide if its worth it to scavenge there or not.  You may find nothing or the mother load!...or a trap and a jackass waiting to cave your skull in with a crowbar.I like how my first OMG YES!! moment was when I found a backpack so I could carry more stuff.  I guess thats the best part of it.  The thrill of finding those essential bits and pieces that you need and surviving those moments where you are attacked.The combat requires you to be thoughtful and tactical, until someone gives in or dies.  So you have to read the text box to see what is going on in that fight and do what you can accordingly.  One mess up and you are done.I like whats been done with this game.  You get the feel that everything is your enemy, from the human, the creatures and the world itself.  Hell you are just as likely to freeze to death as you are to be bludgeoned to death.  It will keep you on your toes.Give this a game a try, it will keep you engrossed for a long time and for what...a 60-70MB download?  I'm behind that all the way.

content:
er 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								Why I have stopped playing NEO Scavenger.  First of all congratulations on creating this game.  Its a very very good game. This is the first and possibly only review I have ever been compelled to write on steam and its something to be said for the quality of this game that I want to save this game for me and not put it in my discard pile. I hesitated about giving this a yes review for the reason that there is no save function.  I get what you are trying to do with death being death however after spending over one hundred hours and near twenty or thirty attempts just to get as far as the gate of detroit (once)... in the last three cases doing nothing but hunting and hiding in a forest making leather armour (mod?) for nigh on twenty hours of play time only to be slaughtered by two dog men half an hour after setting out for the city then doing the same thing in another game, spending this time ten hours (of real life time)  in a forest making leather armour only to be slaughtered by three men as soon as I left the forest not even being able to run away and then doing the same thing, ten hours in a forest hunting and making armour,  only to be slaughtered while I slept without even waking up even though I had multiple noise traps in place.  Then I tried cheating using a mod to add every skill but it had lost its charm because of this becoming too easy.  I dont want a walkthough,  want a hard playthrough but please not a hundred of them, I dont have the time. I have stopped playing this game because I dont have this sort of time to spend to get no where in a game.  I choose not to play again to try and get somewhere in the plot only then to later get slaughtered having spent a hundred hours progressing the plot and have to start all over again.  I want to play it through and I commend you for having this idea to have this "when your dead your dead" idea but I actually have a real life to survive in and I simply dont have time to spend too much of it locked into this game.  Yes, have an Iron man mode for the realism of the survival aspect of the game, but until there is a save function I will not be returning to this game.  I recommend this game to anyone who has a hundred hours to spend just to get out of the starting blocks.EDIT... I have changed this from NO to YES to NO to YES... Its too good not to reccomend.  And... then... I started another game... Dan... I hate you... I love you... I hate you... I love you... please add an iron man function your driving me insane.

content:
er 21, 2014
												This is quite possibly the most well-thought-out game I've ever had the pleasure of experiencing. I can't speak from experience as to how accurate this game nails the zombie apocalypse because personally I have not been in one, but from the fact that I'm a zombie fanatic I can say this game is quite realistic when it comes to living in a wasteland.You wake up in a cryogenic facility with something (You later find out it's one of the game's meany creatures, a Dogman) trying to break in. You select your skills and use them to your advantage to defeat the beast, and then you are sent into the massive and unforgiving world that is NEO: Scavenger.This game absolutely nails scavenging. You search around for ages finding useless, irrelevant items such as string and broken glass bottles but that feeling of pure, unadulterated satisfaction when you find some of the more useful items such as a backpack or especially a crowbar, is amazing. Don't get me wrong, this game is unforgiving. As you'll read down below, someone didn't feel like boiling the water they found, got cholera, and died. That's the kind of thing you have to expect on a daily basis from this game. I once forgot to set my noise trap and was murdered by a guy with a meat cleaver in my sleep. I had a shotgun and a noise trap, but it was in my backpack and I didn't feel like getting it out. Another time, I shot and killed a deer, took the meat, put it in my backpack and forgot to cure it, and proceeded to eat it a few hours later after it had spoiled. I got some sort of weird disease and died after hours of diahorrea and blood loss. And while it's unforgiving, it's ultimately very satisfying to play. You find youself getting killed, cursing the game out, and then coming back a few hours later for seconds. And that one rare playthrough where you don't die a horrible, painful death, you just feel awesome. I have tons of screenshots I've taken of the various times when I've had a surplus of stuff.Also the developer, Daniel, is always reaching out to his fans. I'm personally friends with him here on Steam because I wanted to ask a question, so I shot him a friend request and he responded.If you are thinking about getting this game, get this game.If you are not thinking about getting this game, get this game.If you hate this game with a passion, get this game.If you're going to propose to your SO, buy them this game and put it in a virtual box.

content:
er 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is utterly amazing.  Don't be put off by the mildly ugly graphics.  You will forget them in no time.  What makes this game mind blowing is that it is a rogue-ish game with permadeath, yet it doesn't feel like it.  Sure, the first few times you play you are going to measure your lifespan in hours, but once you get the hang of it you realize that survival is all up to you and completely possible for very long periods of time.  I am writting this after burning a solid 6 hours on this game in a single sitting.  In that entire time I had thrills, upsets, and close calls, but never died.  This is a rougalike game to be sure, but don't let that cause you to run screaming.The survival aspects of this game are absolutely awesome.  You find yourself searching for food and water, planning ahead, and deciding when it is worth a risky encounter.  There is no "I am a bad guy" badge on people.  See a fellow stranger in the distance?  It is up to you if you want to use surprise to take out a possible threat, or wave and see if he is friendly and wants to talk.  Do you risk a fire to boil water, knowing it might attract a threat?  When it gets dark, do you stumble blindly looking for a good camp, or take a risky spot in the open and hope for the best?  What do you do when you wake up to find a melon head stolen your weapon and backpack; grab a stick and give chase, stalk them, what?  There are always so many options, and that doesn't even get into the tactical turn based combat!The combat, while simple on its face is complex and interesting.  Planning is rewarded, but so is on the spot craftiness.   The the game never demands a split second decision, so you have time to ponder your move and roll the dice.  It lets you do so many crafty things and it tends to behave as you would expect.  For instance, imagine you come accross some scary looking person who looks like they want to eat you, and have a host of options.  Do you sneak in close and try and stab him with your trust spear, hoping that this game awesome wound system will let you stun and cripple the guy before he realizes you are there?  Do you try and slip away before he sees  you?  Maybe you decide to bluff and at a distance try pointing your rifle (with no bullets in it) at him, trying to scare him off, if he charges anyways, flip that rifle around and show him the butt of it.  You can jump out of concleament and egg him on, hoping in the rush to get  to you he gives you a solid opening to land the first blow.  Perhaps you get out your old butchers cleaver and start the fight by charging him over onto the ground, and hacking him apart before he can get up.  Hey, he might not even a bad guy, you can always just wave from a distance offering friendly chat and see what he does.This game is so unassuming, but it is solildly on my top 5 for 2014, and for the value for the price, it is easily #1.  It says "early access", but as far as I can tell, this is a full game.  This game is an absolute gem.  The worst thing about this game is that there are so many things that might scare people off from what is an awesome experience; perm death, ugly graphics, early access, a slightly obscure interface (until you get the hang of it), and a strange theme.  Don't let any of these things scare you off.  This game is amazing!  I can't even imagine what it will be once it is out of early access.  Don't wait for a sale, buy it now.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								I've sunk at least 50 hours into this game (I used to play the demo a lot...I was broke!) and I can honestly say that this is one of the best work-in-progress games I have ever played. That's not to say that this game is flawless. The games combat system is designed to be extremely punishing. Therefore adding a risk vs. reward element into most things you can do. However, even when equipped with the best gear, it often comes down to random luck. I've flat out shot people in the head, had them survive, stay concious and then shoot through my helmet and kill me. Other times, I've shot people in the leg and had them die. It honestly feels like I'm playing turn-based Call Of Duty when using guns. The melee system is even worse. It doesn't really matter what weapon you have or what armor you're wearing if you face a dogman (or any other creature for that matter) and attempt to melee it you're screwed.Also, this game being in a post-apocalyptic setting, you have to scavenge for resources (food, water, clothing, armor, etc.). While normally I would be all for this type of mechanic, especially considering the setting, the speed you run through your resources is ridiculous and, at times, can make the game extremely boring as you get stuck in an endless cycle of, find city, scavenge city, use resources found in city, repeat. While this isn't always true, it is for a large majority of the time. However, the story elements that are slowly being implemented are making this game much more dynamic and the resource system is becoming less and less of an issue.Where this game shines and puts it head and shoulders about the competition is its realism. Most games shy away from the possibilities of what a post-apocalyptic society could become, but not NEO Scavenger. From the arena, to the gated city of Detroit, this game feels extremely realistic in its setting, something many other games can't claim.If this game was released today, I'd give it a 6/10. But for an early access game, easily a 8/10.

content:
er 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								(Disclaimer: English is not my native language, expect some typos and grammar errors.)Oh my.... Where do I start?I came to find this game thanks to ''James Recommends'' from Extra Credits. So I knew that, based on his review, this game was going to be good. But... when I played it, I realized that my expectatives of ''Good'' were an utter underestimation. The game wasn't ''Good'', it was ''DAMN EPIC!!''.For a game with less than 100MB of size, this game stands WAAAAAY HIGHER than many Million Dollars AAA titles when it comes to survival; not even Fallout:New Vegas or State of Decay can hold a candle to NS when it comes to TRUE SURVIVAL. Which, when combined with Rogue-like makes for a WHOLE NEW GAME every time you play it; one in which you can never know if you'll succeed or fail until either of them shows up (Like when I found the Crowbar, some Binoculars and a Sauce Pan on the first town and I thought I was winning, only to freeze to death because I never found any shoes or clothes).Unlike in those games where you charge into a group of enemies with just a knife and an angry roar, knowing that if you die, you can just hit the Load Save button, in this game, you gotta think out real carefully each of your moves. Just as you would do if you were in the player's shoes (or bare feet). This makes the game feel extremely real and complex. ''Do you sneak up on that scavenger to kill him while he's asleep to steal his shoes and his gun? You already know that almost every gun you see lacks ammo, but what if this one's loaded? What if you trip on something and wake him up? You could end up losing all you've gathered so far, and there's a high chance you won't encounter most of that stuff again.''That's the feeling you get. And that's not something I've been able to feel with any AAA titles.Just a warning, tho; be prepared to die a thousand times, even right after the start. More than once I stepped into the first area just to be torn to shreds by a Feral Dog.My only critics to this game are the following:-Crafting Instructions are just too vague.The crafting system's utterly complex, but the instructions and recipes are even worse. You can't just figure out what do they say or what do they require until you go read the wiki. Perhaps if the items had some sort of Status Screen that told you what properties do they have, it'd be much easier to do this, as just figuring it out can take THOUSANDS of tries.-The Full Map is too hard to understand.At simple glance it looks just like a 300% Zoom on a SNES-era Sprite. You can't even tell what's what and even those places that are marked, it's hard to make out WHERE is the mark, as all you see is a big word. (Dunno if the iSlab or Smarphone's GPS Apps make it look better. Never gotten any of those.). I know this must be hard to do with a randomized map, but right now, there's just no real purpose to use the Full Map other than locating the Glow.-The Full Bottles' colors are confusing.Whiskey are orange-colored when full of whiskey, but also when full of water. Same goes for the Corn-a-Colas which are yellow. This can lead to a lot of confusion at the time of picking up stuff or even drinking. More than once I've been carrying around whiskey bottles filled with both water and whiskey and I've accidentaly drank Whiskey because I thought it was water and got drunk, which often led to death. This issue can be easily fixed with a couple palette swaps, so I hope it's fixed by the time the game leaves Early Access.-MOAR STUFF!No, seriously, this game needs more stuff, it's already cool enough as it is, but it could be even cooler. The current Item Pool is just too small for such a neigh-infinite world of random possiblities, so it's a bit sad that, once you manage to get some clothes and shoes to stay alive, they're almost always THE SAME. (Your shoes, the Hoodie, three shirts, some Cargo Pants and a Backpack if you're lucky are what you always end up wearing.). A game this big should have at least twelve variants of every piece of cloth or shoes.Aside from those, I have no other complains. This game has the markings of an Indie Masterpiece, and so far, it hasn't let me down. So I hope it has become even more of a Masterpiece by the time it leaves Early Access.
